Is your company rushing AI adoption? Ô∏è

Many organizations rush into AI adoption, adding tools without a clear direction.

The result? Wasted resources, fragmented solutions, and minimal impact.

The pitfalls of speed-driven AI adoption:

Ô∏èLack of alignment: Implementing AI without tying it to business goals creates inefficiencies.
Ô∏èPoor adoption: Teams struggle when they lack training or a clear use case.
Ô∏èTool-first mindset: AI initiatives fail when they focus on technology rather than real problems.

Strategic AI adoption starts with:

‚ÜíDefining clear objectives. What specific problem will AI solve?
‚ÜíEnsuring team readiness. Are employees trained and aligned with AI-driven changes?
‚ÜíFocusing on integration. How does AI fit into existing workflows for real impact?

Leaders who prioritize strategy over speed build AI solutions that scale, deliver ROI, and drive meaningful transformation.

At Mchange, we help organizations craft AI adoption strategies that are practical, scalable, and outcome-driven.

 Ready to take a strategic approach? DM me or book a free strategy call on our website.

I recently saw a "VC thought leader" say "successful" founders were working 100+ hours a week ‚ÄçÔ∏è

On top of being delusional (data from PitchBook shows that profitable founders average 45-55 hours per week) - we should stop glorifying the "hustle p*rn" for the sake of it‚Ä¶

Instead, let's focus on:

- 40 hours of focused work
- Working on something profitable
- Being part of a team you trust
- Being independent and building what customers want
- Going on actual vacations
- Doing work when it's meaningful
- Being in control
- Making decisions daily

The real metrics that matter:

Hustle Culture Path:

- 100+ hour weeks
- Burnout in 2 years
- VC-backed stress
- 7% ownership
- $4M after 7 years (if you‚Äôre lucky enough to have a profitable exit)

Sustainable Path:

- 40-hour weeks
- $5M annual profit
- 100% ownership
- Team of 10 or less
- Freedom to choose

Build for freedom, not exits.

postsData.content:
Most companies try to scale chaos.

They believe growth means:

 Working harder
 Hiring faster
 Moving quicker

But sustainable growth?
It's built on simple, repeatable systems.

After building 7 companies,
Here's what I learned actually works:

1. Clean Up Your Core Engines
‚Ü≥ Fix sales and delivery systems first
‚Ü≥ Everything else is a distraction

2. Trust The System
‚Ü≥ Document every key process
‚Ü≥ Your team needs clarity, not control

3. Build Two-Way Trust
‚Ü≥ Your team trusts the business
‚Ü≥ The business trusts the team

4. Find Hidden Growth
‚Ü≥ Look where others aren't
‚Ü≥ Double down on what works quietly

5. Track What Matters
‚Ü≥ Define clear success metrics
‚Ü≥ Review and adjust weekly

6. Create Predictable Results
‚Ü≥ Focus on consistent delivery
‚Ü≥ Build repeatable processes

7. Stop Being The Hero
‚Ü≥ Build systems that run without you
‚Ü≥ Enable decisions, don't make them all

8. Test Your Success
‚Ü≥ Could you leave for 6 weeks?
‚Ü≥ If not, you have a job, not a company

Simple systems beat complex plans.
But they require ruthless focus.

Pick one area.
Make it repeatable.
Let it compound.

Which area will you make predictable first?

postsData.content:
Oman Introduces New Regulations for Part-Time Work

The Ministry of Labour has rolled out Ministerial Decision No. 13/2025, introducing updated regulations for part-time work across Oman.

This decision is set to reshape employment opportunities for a wide range of individuals, including students, job seekers, retirees, and current employees looking for flexible work arrangements.

Here are the key highlights:
 Flexible Opportunities for Students:
Students aged 15 and above can now take on part-time jobs with parental approval. Importantly, they don‚Äôt need permission from their schools or universities, provided their work doesn‚Äôt interfere with academic responsibilities.

 Defined Part-Time Hours & Wages:
Part-time work is capped at 25 hours per week (minimum of 4 hours per day), with a minimum wage of RO 3 per hour. However, employers and employees can agree on a lower rate if needed.

 Omani Nationals First:
The decision ensures that part-time opportunities are reserved for Omani nationals, aiming to boost local employment.

 Worker Protections in Place:
Employers must adhere to occupational health and safety standards, provide training, and ensure timely wage payments. Part-time workers are also required to be registered in the Social Security Fund.

 Recognition for Experience:
Students will receive experience certificates for the time worked, adding value to their professional development early on.

This move strikes a balance between promoting flexible work opportunities while safeguarding the well-being and growth of the workforce, especially young students eager to gain real-world experience.

What are your thoughts on these new regulations? Could this inspire other countries to adopt similar policies to support youth employment and flexible work? Let‚Äôs hear your insights!
postsData.commentAdded: Great initiative! These regulations not only empower Omani youth but also set a precedent for flexible work that other nations might follow. #YouthEmployment

Stop Focusing Only on Experienced Candidates! Here‚Äôs Why Fresh Talent Can Be a Game-Changer.

We often see job listings packed with experience requirements. The hiring team thinking is clear: more experience means less training, faster onboarding, and immediate impact.

But here‚Äôs a thought‚Äînewcomers and career changers bring unique strengths to the table:
üü™ Fresh Perspectives: They offer a unique outlook and creative ideas that can disrupt the status quo. Unconstrained by ‚Äúthe way things have always been done,‚Äù they‚Äôre often the source of innovative solutions.

postsData.content:
BIOMIMICRY CONTINUUM ‚Äì Part 5 ‚Äì CURATING Agentic Expertise
Multidisciplinary expertise is critical to correctly define the key premises driving problem analysis and solution architecture, and the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem (left image) enables capturing that expertise as a reusable computing asset.

The current AI chaos is due to 70 years of narrow and unexamined premises. The promise of AGI in the 1950s was rooted in premises that have been disproven by real-world evidence but blindly adhered to by those making today‚Äôs AGI claims. Key examples:

-Premise: language is the source of intelligence
-Reality: intelligence is the source of language - babies are intelligent before they can speak

-Premise: data is a representation of the real world
-Reality: data is the output of a machine and represents only what the machine was designed to capture

-Premise: the brain constructs objects by identifying frequent patterns of object bits
-Reality: the brain contains networks of abstract concept cells which fire when the concepts are presented in diverse versions and formats (text, image, sound, etc.)

-Premise: neural networks imitate how the brain reasons by processing massive data exhaustively
-Reality: the brain computes the relevance of inputs using inhibition networks, filtering out over 99.99% of sensory data

There are more, but the point is that the main objectives of curation are:
1-Ensure that knowledge from all relevant domains is included in the ontology
2-Map the relevant knowledge concepts across the domains to problem and solution concepts
3-Maintain the landscape concepts (science, business, regulation, etc.) reasonably updated

To enable these objectives, the custodian systems must support:
1-Biomimetic digital twinning of problem and solution concepts
2-Independent update by authorized experts
2-Simulation and testing of the impact of proposed updates across the ontology architecture

The methodology and technology to build this type of biomimetic digital twin ecosystem exist, we have produced published results, and I have discussed this in my posts.

The vision of the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem in the image, however, is in early stages and will require committed partners with the necessary resources who want to participate in shaping the implementation of this new paradigm.
postsData.commentAdded: Fascinating insights! Embracing multidisciplinary expertise is vital for redefining AGI‚Äôs future. Excited to see how the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem evolves!

Don‚Äôt let cold call objections throw you off.

Turn them into your strongest advantage.

Tired of running into the same objections?

The best salespeople don‚Äôt wing it‚Äîthey prepare.

Here‚Äôs how you can level up your approach to objections:

‚Üí Anticipate the most common pushbacks and prepare tailored responses.
‚Üí Reframe objections as opportunities to demonstrate your value.
‚Üí Practice your delivery until it feels natural and confident.

ùó™ùóÆùóªùòÅ ùòÅùóµùó≤ ùó£ùóóùóô ùòÉùó≤ùóøùòÄùó∂ùóºùóª ùóºùó≥ ùòÅùóµùó∂ùòÄ ùó∞ùóµùó≤ùóÆùòÅ ùòÄùóµùó≤ùó≤ùòÅ + ùóΩùóÆùóøùòÅ ùü≠?

 ùóöùó≤ùòÅ ùó∂ùòÅ ùóµùó≤ùóøùó≤:

Here are some of the most common cold call objections and how to handle them:

1.) "I'm not interested."

‚á¢ Say: "Out of curiosity, when was the last time you evaluated this?"

‚á¢ Respectfully challenge: "Of course, you‚Äôre not. You don‚Äôt even know why I called yet."

2.) "How did you get my number?"

‚á¢ Be upfront: "I found your contact through a database of decision-makers like you."

‚á¢ Stay calm and professional: "It sounds like this wasn‚Äôt something you were expecting‚Äîam I right?"

3.) "Send me an email."

‚á¢ Make it relevant: "Sure‚Äîwhat‚Äôs the most important thing for me to include?"

‚á¢ Suggest a follow-up: "Would a quick chat now save time over emails back and forth?"

4.) "We‚Äôre happy with what we have."

‚á¢ Validate their position: "That makes sense. But if you found something that worked better, would you at least take a look?"

‚á¢ Ask subtly: "Good to hear! Just so I know, what do you like most about your current provider?"

5.) "We‚Äôre already working with someone else."

Respect their loyalty: "Makes sense! Do you ever evaluate solutions like this to stay competitive?"

Open the door: "If a better option came along, would you at least take a look?"

This cheat sheet ensures you‚Äôre ready for any curveball a prospect might throw.

 ùóöùó≤ùòÅ ùòÅùóµùó≤ ùó≥ùòÇùóπùóπ ùó¥ùòÇùó∂ùó±ùó≤ + ùóΩùóÆùóøùòÅ ùóú:

postsData.content:
How a girl from Mississippi became one of the most influential women in the world.

It's fascinating to see how Oprah's journey unfolded from her humble beginnings to becoming a global icon.

Here‚Äôs the breakdown:

‚Üí Started as a local news anchor, fired for being "too emotional"
‚Üí Took over a failing talk show and turned it into a cultural phenomenon
‚Üí Built a media empire that spans TV, film, publishing, and philanthropy

And the numbers speak for themselves:

 25 years of The Oprah Winfrey Show (highest-rated talk show in history)
 10M+ magazine readers at the peak of O, The Oprah Magazine
 $2.6B net worth (self-made billionaire)
 22 Emmy Awards and countless accolades

But here‚Äôs what makes Oprah different 

She didn‚Äôt just build a brand - she built a MOVEMENT.

1. She made vulnerability her superpower.

Oprah shared her personal struggles - poverty, abuse, weight issues - and turned them into a source of strength for millions.

2. She championed empowerment.

From her book club to her leadership academy, she‚Äôs always focused on lifting others up.

3. She mastered the art of connection.

Whether interviewing celebrities or everyday people, Oprah made everyone feel seen and heard.

The best part?

She‚Äôs still the same authentic, empathetic person who started her show in 1986.

Her success formula is simple but powerful:

 Be unapologetically yourself
 Use your platform to make a difference
 Stay consistent, even as you evolve

And her audience? They‚Äôre LOYAL.

Why?

Because Oprah never lost her "girl from Mississippi" vibe.

P.S. What do you think about Oprah and her journey?

Ô∏è Repost if you enjoyed this breakdown.

Catherine Smith
Catherine Smith
postsData.content:
Are you meeting your clients where they are?

Your potential clients may be anywhere from not a clue about your health program to super savvy.

When it comes to creating a message they hear and act on, where they are matters‚Äîa lot.

Imagine explaining whole-food, plant-based eating to someone who hasn‚Äôt given their diet a second thought‚Äîversus someone who‚Äôs watched every nutrition documentary out there, but hasn‚Äôt been able to implement what they learned.

Those are two completely different conversations.

Now think about the moment you introduce the details of your program, or invite someone to ‚ÄúBook a call‚Äù.

That post or email would make absolutely no sense to someone who‚Äôs totally unaware. But the super savvy person? They might be ready to jump on your offer.

That‚Äôs why knowing which stage of awareness your potential clients are in is so important.

 Unaware ‚Äì They don‚Äôt realize their daily habits are contributing to their health issues.
 Problem-aware ‚Äì They feel the struggle (low energy, poor sleep, chronic pain), but don‚Äôt know what to do‚Äîor even if there‚Äôs a solution.
 Solution-aware ‚Äì They know lifestyle changes can help, but are unsure which approach is right.
 Program-aware ‚Äì They are considering options, trying to decide which program fits best.
 Most-aware ‚Äì They are ready to commit but just need a final nudge.

If your message doesn‚Äôt match the stage they‚Äôre in, it simply won‚Äôt land.

When you map out your customer journey based on these stages, you ensure your messages meet them exactly where they are.

What‚Äôs one piece of messaging you could create today that speaks to a specific stage of awareness?

comments.commentText: Spot on, Catherine Smith! What's the #1 mistake you see when in comes to marketing for the right stage of awareness?

What I see is business owners not having had enough real-life conversations with their clients to really know how their potential clients are thinking, feeling and acting in each stage. 

So instead of speaking to their needs, they talk about what they themselves know about their field and the impact it can have. Or they start talking too soon about their offer and get frustrated by the lack of response.

How about you, what's the #1 mistake you see?

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely! Tailoring your message to clients awareness stages is key. It personalizes their journey and increases engagement! Whats your next step?

Many people stop at "no" in a salary negotiation. 

You get the gusto to ask for 15% more, they refuse or don't budge, and then you quietly accept or move on, right?

If this has happened to you, here's a 3-step approach (and the third step is a salary-saver)

Instead of giving up hope for your ideal number, try this:

1. Bring data and comparison values to help support your request

2. Express your enthusiasm and future vision of how you'll be able to deliver results for this team and company (do your best to estimate in numbers) -- and ask if they feel the same.

If so...

3. Ask how you can make a plan to reach your ideal number. Have them create it with you with measurable benchmarks that make sense and a clear timeline.

Get on the same side of the table with your hiring manager.

You're worth it.

SHOW them that in the way you negotiate, too.


You've GOT this.

And I've got your back if you need help -- just send me a DM.
